text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 9.7.11, Abandoned Property.

IRM 9.7.11 has been reviewed and certified by Warrants & Forfeiture to reflect current instructions to staff as of the date of this manual transmittal. The date on TRIDOC 9.7.11.1 is updated to reflect the review and certification of the IRM.

) Criminal Investigation (CI) may come into possession of abandoned or unclaimed property when property seized as evidence is no longer needed when items such as personal effects not subject to forfeiture are left in or the premises of property seized for forfeiture. These items should be to the lawful owner. (
) This section covers the process and procedures for the return of other unclaimed property. (

) The abandonment process is similar to the administrative forfeiture However, abandoned or other unclaimed property found by or in the and sion of federal agencies is subject to the provisions of the Federal Property Authorities and Administrative Services Act of
, as amended (
USC §
) The authority for the abandoned property procedures is contained in Title USC §
, Abandoned or Unclaimed Property on Government Premises; of Federal Regulations (CFR) Title
, Public Contracts and Property ment, Chapter
, Federal Management Regulation, Part
, Sale of Personal Property; Part
, Disposition of Seized, Forfeited, Voluntarily Abandon, and Unclaimed Personal Property; and Chapter
, Department Justice, Part
, Utilization, Donation, or Disposal of Abandoned and Personal Property. (
) The General Services Administration (GSA) prescribes and issues the Management Regulations. (

) Abandoned or other unclaimed assets must be inventoried and tracked on Asset Forfeiture and Retrieval System (AFTRAK). Refer to the Asset Abandoned Process Guide located on the CI Web for procedures for tracking property on AFTRAK. (

) Abandoned or other unclaimed property shall remain in the custody of and the responsibility of CI as the finding agency until disposition. Criminal and Storage of gation shall be responsible for the care and handling of abandoned or Property unclaimed property pending disposition. (

) Abandoned or other unclaimed currency or monetary instruments shall not deposited into the Treasury Suspense Account. Abandoned or other currency or monetary instruments may be deposited into the Internal Service (IRS) Suspense Account until an owner files a proper claim or title vests in the United States. (

) Abandoned or other unclaimed property not subject to forfeiture such as personal effects of a defendant or occupant left in vehicles, vessels, or or on the premises of real property should be removed prior to transfer of custody of the seized asset and retained by CI pending return to the (

) The seized property contractor will not take custody of abandoned or other unclaimed property, defined in the Statement of Work as “held property”. In cases where items not subject to forfeiture are temporarily left in or on transferred to the seized property contractor, a separate inventory shall be completed.

If the owner of abandoned or other unclaimed property is known, a letter shall be sent to the owner within

days of finding such property, by certified mail to the owner’s address of record, notifying him/her that the property may be claimed by the owner or the owner’s designee and that if the property is not claimed within

) Upon receipt of a claim for abandoned or other unclaimed property, an gation shall be conducted to determine the merits of the claim, and a report Relating to shall be submitted to the determining official in accordance with the for a petition for remission or mitigation covered in IRM
, Claims and Petitions. (
) Claims shall be sworn and shall include the following information in clear and concise terms (
CFR

): Procedures a. a complete description of the property including serial numbers, if any b. the interest of the claimant in the property, as owner, mortgagee, or otherwise, supported by bills of sale, contracts, mortgages, or other factory documentary evidence c. the facts and circumstances, established by satisfactory proof, relied by the claimant to justify the granting of the claim (

) If the claim for abandoned or other unclaimed personal property is filed title has vested in the United States, the determining official shall not grant claim unless the claimant establishes a valid, good faith interest in the property. (

) If the claim for abandoned or other unclaimed personal property is filed after title vested in the United States, the determining official shall not grant the claim unless the claimant: a. establishes that he/she would have a valid, good faith interest in the property had title not vested in the United States; and b. establishes that he/she had no actual or constructive notice, prior to the vesting of title in the United States, that the property was in the custody CI and that title, after the appropriate time period, would vest in the States (

) A claimant shall be presumed to have constructive notice upon publication in suitable medium concerning the property unless there were circumstances which prevented him from knowing of the status of the property or having the opportunity to see the notice. (

) Title reverts to the owner where a proper claim is filed within three years the date of vesting title in the United States, but if the property has been in official use, transferred for official use, or sold at the time the property claim approved, title shall not revert back to the former owner. The former owner shall instead obtain reimbursement in accordance with
CFR

9.7 Asset Seizure and Forfeiture

Property declared abandoned cannot be transferred to other Federal, state, or local law enforcement agencies, or foreign countries through equitable However, these agencies may apply for transfer of abandoned property
